comments.commentBody: Simply brilliant.  We the people, perfectly follow the definition of insanity - doing same thing over and over while expecting different results.

Time Warner Cable in Manhattan has, as usual, completely fouled up on the Olympics connection. It's been impossible over the last three days to establish the well-advertised and technologically simple stream due to TWC's mind-boggling technical incompetence.
You want to correct that year, right?
Who knows, Viv? it would explain a lot....
What's to explain Leapy?  I live in a castle in the Transylvania neighborhood in Chicago.  That's somewhere between Bridgeport and Wrigleyville.
I remember the 1893 Chicago World's Fair.  I am afraid of heights and that FERRIS WHEEL still gives me nightmares.
Bryan - good point.  Thanks for the correction.

Arno,
"Early twentieth century warming started suddenly in 1910 and stopped equally suddenly in 1940. There was no parallel sudden increase of carbon dioxide and this rules out the greenhouse effect by laws of radiation physics. Its most likely cause is solar effects, a continuation of coming out of the Little Ice Age."
Greenhouse gases are not the only forcing at work on climate. If you look at the amount of energy added to the climate by greenhouse gases (1500x10^21 joules since 1960 - if memory serves), it is far in excess of what is needed to account for the observed warming. This means that other forcings or feedbacks are in play and have reduced the net amount of energy absorbed by the surface/atmosphere. Changes in clouds, changes in amount of energy going to the oceans, changes in aerosol are all candidates. Around 1940, great increases in industrialization probably resulted in lots of airborne particulate matter that may have changed albedo enough to account for the changes - improvements in air quality later in the century may have allowed warming to resume. I do not think that the data on global air quality are good enough to prove that.
Your insistence that warming track CO2 concentration exactly is simply not realistic and is wrong. These other factors will impact the timing and intensity of the resulting warming (climate sensitivity). Plus your linking of the solar effects to the exit of the little ice age is confused
Dinner is on- i'm gone

Chuck Wilson

Yet sea-level rise remains inside the long-rend and in fact in a multi-year deceleration.

Record heat and far below record sea level rise - this must be the 'new' math.
Sea level has been rising per century for 400 years.  Recent rises are lower than prior rise.  How do you account for this anti-AGW-theory situation?

R. Crosby,

Was over 3mm .... now more like 0-1.7mm - was over 3mm during the warm-phase of the 60 year oscillation. Longer trend 1.8mm +/-.
this question was directed to Kip and Chris-

Nick,

I'm simply asking the questions that do not seem to be getting asked in a meaningful way in the current research arena. And for the record, I would certainly not support using "science" at will, and I would ask perhaps for a more careful reading of what I wrote to Andrew.

So this is a generic question pertainlng to industry- funded academic reports and I really want to know what people think:

What should our level of concern be when a non peer-reviewed study is funded by the beneficiaries of the implementation of the recommendations of that study, and when the study is widely cited by the beneficiaries/ industry in order to influence public opinion, elected officials and policy?

Thanks,

Lisa

Phil "+185mm per year" 185 mm=7.28 inches.

WUWT is an anti-science and denialist web site. If you are getting your "science" from there, you may as well get your science from Boris Karloff movies.

Major universities have become so driven by the need to expand endowments and secure grants to cover their increasingly inefficient modus operandi that they increasingly employ academic "hired guns" who mimic the  behavior of early 20th century European intellectuals who were justly condemned by Julian Benda for committing "trahison des clercs." Today's clerisy may not beat the drums of war and racism as their predecesors did, but the havoc they are wreaking to the cause of intellectual integrity and objective research will have dire consequences for the entire human race far beyond the ivory tower.

James, you almost had me until this statement:

"You, Madam, are not a scientist. You are not an engineer. You are not a public policy analyst. I would be very surprised to learn that you even a hard sciences major as an undergraduate."

Research engineering is all the "hard science," ten times more math and experiments that have to work. You may want to put out a public apology - maybe run a full page ad in NYT print addition - for a week. In the mean time I should get the Nobel Peace Prize for restraint - and not using cuss words in a blog post comment section.

Going from policy to practice in environmental protection is very difficult. Unfortunately, all the policy experts are sitting on the sidelines - until they can find funding from someone - or the problem gets big enough that everyone goes into emergency response mode and money gets thrown around. What we have here is a dog pile on a few researchers bold (or unlucky) enough to be looking into the details.

Policy to practice transition reminds me of T.S. Eliot's "The Hollow Men" from the fifth verse:

Between the idea
And the reality
Between the motion
And the act
Falls the Shadow

And then the poem ends as follows:

This is the way the world ends
This is the way the world ends
This is the way the world ends
Not with a bang but a whimper.

James, I've already accepted your apology so no need to put out the add.

What an offensive comment. On what grounds do you suggest that Ms. Wright is an opponent of GMO crops or vaccines? A classic straw-man argument: ascribe to your opponent characteristics that she doesn't possess, then criticize her for them.

I've seen this form of attack repeatedly from pro-frackers:: "Oh, those who oppose us are just wild-eyed environmental extremists who hate science." Another one: "They're elitists who don't care about the poor; they don't want their view ruined as they drive their fancy cars through the countryside."

It's a sign of the gas industry's desperation, that they must fall back on such ludicrous arguments. It's an argument derived from PR campaign tactics, not science.

Are you unaware, sir, that the gas industry has financed a decade-long campaign to silence critics of fracking? That they rely on PR and advertising firms to push their perspective? That, according to Josh Fox, they have spent $237,000,000 to push their perspective, ferociously attacking all opponents?

Did you know that the 2004 EPA study of fracking was about to be repudiated by the EPA when Cheney's task force made the point moot with its environmental law exemptions?

http://www.ucsusa.org/scientific_integrity/abuses_of_science/oil-extract...

That's from the Union of Concerned SCIENTISTS Scientific Integrity Committee. Not the Union of Concern Wackos.

We have AMPLE reason to suspect the industry of trying to game the system, including the science.

This comment seems to assume that "science" has established that fracking for and the burning of natural gas is a great boon to humankind, similar to vaccinations. This is hardly established fact.

Also, how dare anyone anyone who doesn't have a college degree in the "hard sciences" comment on public policy or even dream of questioning prestigious institutions or Nobel prize winners.

Following the money is apparently a privelege reserved for those with prestigious credentials.

First off, I'm not a paid blogger.

Second off, why obfuscate. You think Prof Deutch (let's not deny the man his honorific) is a corporate shill with zero academic integrity. You think MIT, the most presitgious body of scientific learning in the history of man, is nothing more than a mouthpiece for "big oil and gas" (whatever that is -- apparently Cheniere and Exxon are somehow part of the same mysterious cabal). And, you think Nobel Prize winner Stephen Chu (Nobel prize for physics mind you) is toeing some political party line, and selling his reputation for professional advancement.

Ms. Wright, I'll extend to you the credit you failed to extend to Deutch, Chu, and the august members of MIT. I'll tell you exactly what I think of you.

You, Madam, are not a scientist. You are not an engineer. You are not a public policy analyst. I would be very surprised to learn that you even a hard sciences major as an undergraduate.

What you are is a science denier. The opponents of vaccines, the opponents of famine-preventing GMO crops, the opponents of fracking, they all play the same silly little propaganda game. The game you play here - "the ties to industry" game. No credit is giving to the years of underpaid grunt work performed by Dr. Deutch as he built his reputation. No mention of the vast endowment carried by MIT, and the miniscule proportion of funding it recieves from the natural gas industry. No, a single penny of coprorate dollars somehow taints the entire body of work.

I nursed my first child until he was almost 13 months old, but because we were unable to conceive without assisted reproductive medicine & wanted another baby, I could no longer breastfeed once I started the medications to try & get pregnant. It was such a tender, spiritual experience in many ways and I really missed that closeness.

Never being able to successfully carry a viable pregnancy, we were eventually able to adopt a wonderful baby girl 8 years later. After consulting with my pediatrician, I decided to try to induce lactation. We were modestly successful, and able to produce enough milk to nurse her 50% of the time. We did have to supplement with formula. I feel that if I had no other children, no job, and could devote 24 hrs a day to the effort to lactate, it might have resulted in better milk production. However, I came to realize that what was really important was not WHERE her nourishment came from, but that she got enough to eat and that it was provided by someone who loved her.

I still had that wonderful, tender experience holding her in my arms and will always be grateful for both of my children & being able to mother them.
rich, you could always move to a country that actually shows most coverage as it happens.....
I tried to watch beach volleyball tofday on my PC from Xfinity, it never came on, just froze. Good thing I have DVR, was able to watch and FF all the prime time events. But I will try again.

I have 20 mb down and pay mightily for it, yet NBC is going to sit there and say "some computers might not be capable, yada yada."  "we have no way to know how widespread the issue is." "we have enough bandwidth"   Says who?   NBC is about 1 thing: Protect Primetime (and Seacrest's wallet). Why are all their other channels dark when primetime is on?  I would rather get results off Twitter and watch reruns of Lockup than put up with any more of this.
I tried to watch beach volleyball yesterday from Xfinity, it never came on, just froze. Luckily I have a DVR and was able to record and FF prime time on TV. But I will try again.
Let's all hope that Rep. Camp has a full and speedy recovery.

Just to stickle a little, Viv: Flushing Meadows is immediately adjacent to what is now La Guardia Airport (opened in 1939, coincidentally, as New York Municipal Airport).

Idylwild > JFK is also in Queens, but sits more than 12 miles away to the southeast.
Thanks for the correction, cruciform.

Dim memories of the 1939 Worlds Fair in Flushing Meadows, later to be Idylwild Airport and eventually JFK. I was 4, and my main memories are the Perisphere and Trylon, the parachute jump, and the little Heinz pickle pin that I had for years and years afterwards.  Actually, change "main" to "only."

Our longest ally is France. They were our allies when England was our enemy, remember?

Otherwise, good comment. : )

No, the British don't get to vote in our elections. (Even some AMERICANS won't get to vote in our elections, if the (R) have their way.)

But that does not mean we should discount their opinions... which are pretty overwhelmingly negative about Mr. Romney.

The American President should command respect from the content of his character; Mr. Romney has broken the low-water mark set by Mr. Bush II.

The Big Trade-Off? Dumping the American consumer... who suddenly seems to have too little money to buy products (how'd that happen?)... for the emerging Chinese, Indian and South American consumer... who suddenly seems to have a lot more.

Those Giant Global Multinational Corporations... they're SO fickle.
Muslims voted for Muslim leaders, who act like Muslims.  That is not "hijacking."  Who did you think they would vote for?  Jeb Bush?

If he (Mitt did) what he did in a relatively safe UK for any US President (or hopeful), I am worried about how carefully he'd walk around the minefields in Israel?

Obama did upstage him by signing off on something Israel would appreciate.

But knowing the Israeli sensibilities, he would either rush to endorse everything Bibi (his 'old friend') wants or do something he would never know, UNLESS pointed out later.

He can hide from the US reporters, but Israeli reporters are not any less forgiving.
